The program received 1,600 applications and highlights the importance of mentorship and marketing support for female entrepreneurs, incorporating social impact into business plans. Stacy's also announced an additional $150,000 in grants for Black female founders through its partnership with Hello Alice.

title: Doritos Seeking Fans To Create Ad For Chance To Air During Return Of NFL Kickoff Weekend
summary: Doritos is launching "Crash from Home," a competition inviting fans to create a TV commercial set to air during NFL Kickoff Weekend, with a $150,000 prize. This initiative revives the spirit of their "Crash the Super Bowl" campaign, offering a platform for aspiring filmmakers while also highlighting Doritos' and PepsiCo's community support efforts, including initiatives for racial equality and COVID-19 relief. Fans have until July 28 to submit their entries.

title: PepsiCo gains more from its snacks business than its beverages business
summary: PepsiCo's second-quarter 2020 results exceeded expectations, largely driven by strong performance in its snacks division, especially Frito-Lay and Quaker Foods, while its beverages business saw declines. The company continued its acquisition strategy during the pandemic, adding Pioneer Foods, Rockstar, and Be & Cheery. PepsiCo anticipates low-single-digit organic revenue growth and core operating margin contraction in the third quarter of 2020.

title: PepsiCo second quarter buffeted by COVID-19 headwinds
summary: PepsiCo's second-quarter performance was negatively impacted by COVID-19 related foodservice closures and reduced consumer traffic, leading to a decline in net income and overall sales. While the North American beverage business faced headwinds, the company's snacks and food divisions, particularly Frito-Lay and Quaker Foods, showed strong growth due to increased at-home consumption. PepsiCo anticipates an uneven recovery in international markets and expects its snacks and food businesses to remain resilient, while beverages should improve in the second half of the year.

title: PepsiCo jumps after Cheetos-Hungry Americans stock up on comfort
summary: PepsiCo's sales surged due to increased at-home snacking on comfort foods like Tostitos, Fritos, and Cheetos during COVID-19 lockdowns, despite a decline in beverage sales. This article also covers Moderna's inclusion in the Nasdaq-100, Australia's push for tech giants to share revenue with news publishers, a strike at Bath Iron Works, RTW Retailwinds' bankruptcy, a projected fall in global coffee consumption, Southwest Airlines' warning of layoffs, Netflix surpassing Disney in market capitalization, Heathrow Airport closing a runway for repairs, and Huawei's sales growth despite restrictions.

title: Diageo announces creation of paper-based bottle for Johnnie Walker
summary: Diageo announced the creation of a 100 percent plastic-free, paper-based spirits bottle made from sustainably sourced wood, set to debut with Johnnie Walker in early 2021. This initiative is part of a new partnership with Pilot Lite to launch Pulpex Ltd., a sustainable packaging technology company. Pulpex Ltd. has also formed a consortium with companies like Unilever and PepsiCo, aiming to launch branded paper bottles in 2021 that are fully recyclable and meet food-safe standards.

title: Diageo to launch Johnnie Walker whisky in paper bottles in 2021
summary: Diageo Plc announced that Johnnie Walker scotch whisky will be available in plastic-free paper bottles made from wood pulp starting in early 2021 to combat plastic waste. Diageo has partnered with Pilot Lite to form Pulpex Ltd, a sustainable packaging company that will also develop paper bottles for other major companies like Unilever Plc and PepsiCo. This initiative aligns with global efforts by consumer product companies to reduce plastic in packaging.

title: Frito-Lay expanding Georgia snack production plant
summary: Frito-Lay, a division of PepsiCo, Inc., is investing $200 million to expand its snack manufacturing plant in Houston County, Georgia. This expansion will create 120 new jobs and includes an additional line for tortilla chips, a line for Baked Cheeto Puffs, space for a future manufacturing line, and a new warehouse. The Perry site is Frito-Lay's largest manufacturing facility in the US, employing over 1,000 people.

title: FedEx's request of Redskins: Change team name
summary: FedEx, the stadium sponsor for the Washington Redskins, formally requested the team change its nickname, citing renewed pressure following social climate shifts. This request comes as investment firms and shareholders urge sponsors like FedEx, Nike, and PepsiCo to sever ties unless the controversial name is changed, impacting the team's future in Washington D.C.

title: Pepsi quietly joining Facebook ad boycott: sources
summary: PepsiCo is secretly joining a growing boycott of Facebook ads due to the social media platform's handling of hate speech. The "global boycott" by the food and beverage giant, which spends billions annually on advertising, will run through July and August, significantly impacting Facebook's bottom line. This move comes as other major companies and advocacy groups pressure Facebook to better police its content after the death of George Floyd.

title: Dow leaves Plastics Industry Association
summary: Dow Inc. has announced its departure from the Plastics Industry Association, following similar moves by major consumer product makers like Coca-Cola Co. and PepsiCo Inc. While previous departures were linked to environmental pressure regarding plastics waste and lobbying, Dow stated its decision was to focus on other industry supply chain relationships. The Plastics Industry Association expressed hope for continued collaboration with Dow.

title: PepsiCo sustainably sourcing more ag raw materials
summary: PepsiCo made significant progress in 2019 towards sustainably sourcing its agricultural raw materials, with nearly 80% verified as sustainably sourced, up from 51% in 2018. The company is on track to meet its goal of 100% sustainable sourcing by the end of 2020 through its Sustainable Farming Program. This initiative also involves regenerative agriculture practices to improve climate impact and soil fertility.

title: PepsiCo improves on health targets
summary: PepsiCo, Inc. made significant progress in 2019 toward its 2025 health targets, including reducing added sugars in beverages, cutting sodium in its food portfolio, and decreasing saturated fat across various product lines. The company expanded the availability of Pepsi Zero Sugar globally and reformulated products like SunChips Harvest Cheddar to meet its nutritional goals. These efforts were detailed in PepsiCo's 2019 Sustainability Report.

title: Colgate-Palmolive to review product's name that translates to 'Black people toothpaste'
summary: Colgate-Palmolive announced it would review the name of its "Darlie" toothpaste, a popular brand in Asia, which translates to "Black people toothpaste." This decision follows renewed criticism over racial inequality and stereotyping, and comes after similar moves by other American brands to reassess offensive branding. The product, co-owned with Hawley & Hazel, had previously changed its name and logo from "Darkie" and a minstrel singer in blackface in 1989 due to public backlash.

title: Mrs. Butterworth, Uncle Ben’s, Colgate, more brands consider changes after Aunt Jemima
summary: Following PepsiCo's announcement to rename Aunt Jemima, several other brands, including Cream of Wheat, Mrs. Butterworth's, Uncle Ben's, and Colgate's Darlie toothpaste, are reviewing their racially charged logos and packaging. These corporate reevaluations are a direct response to the Black Lives Matter protests and increasing scrutiny over systemic racism in branding. Companies like B&G Foods Inc. and Conagra Brands have announced immediate reviews to ensure their brands do not inadvertently contribute to racial stereotypes.

title: Frito Lay
summary: This case study details how Frito-Lay North America collaborated with IBM Consulting and IBM Garage to modernize its operations and enhance customer satisfaction. By implementing Salesforce-based solutions like "Snacks to You" and "Sales Hub," Frito-Lay digitized employee workflows, streamlined delivery routes, and improved sales efficiency for its vast network of retail stores and small businesses. The initiative focused on human-centered design and agile methodologies, resulting in significant operational improvements and a more adaptive business model.

title: Mrs. Butterworth’s, Uncle Ben’s among brands to eliminate racial stereotypes
summary: Conagra Brands, Mars, and B&G Foods announced plans to remove racially stereotypical imagery from their Mrs. Butterworth’s, Uncle Ben’s, and Cream of Wheat brands following PepsiCo's decision regarding Aunt Jemima. These companies expressed solidarity with the Black community and committed to reviewing their packaging to eliminate racial bias. The move reflects a broader industry effort to address systemic racism in branding.

title: Four overseas companies ranked among best places to work in Chile
summary: Four overseas companies, Santander, Zara, PepsiCo Inc., and Finning South America, were recognized among the top ten best places to work in Chile in CompuTrabajo's Best WorkPlaces 2020 ranking. This ranking also highlighted numerous foreign companies across various sectors, including banking, consultancy, hotels, healthcare, food, and retail. The assessment considered various aspects such as work environment, innovation, leadership, career opportunities, wages, and benefits to acknowledge companies that foster excellent corporate cultures.

title: PepsiCo Releases 2019 Sustainability Report; Highlights Progress Toward Helping to Build a More Sustainable Food System
summary: PepsiCo released its 2019 Sustainability Report, detailing significant progress across key areas such as safe water access, sustainable agriculture, and climate action. The company exceeded its safe water access goal five years early and set an ambitious new target to reach 100 million people by 2030, while also announcing a commitment to accelerate climate action with a focus on net-zero emissions by 2050. The report emphasizes PepsiCo's dedication to building a more sustainable food system through collective action and continued investment in environmental and social initiatives.

title: Aunt Jemima and Uncle Ben’s, Rooted in Racist Imagery, to Change
summary: Following the killing of George Floyd and renewed focus on systemic racism, several major food brands are rethinking their imagery. PepsiCo Inc. announced it would retire the Aunt Jemima brand due to its racist origins, and Mars Inc. committed to changing its Uncle Ben's brand. Other companies are also reviewing the packaging for products like Cream of Wheat and Mrs. Butterworth’s.

title: PepsiCo to retire Aunt Jemima brand over imagery ‘based on racial stereotype’
summary: PepsiCo Inc. announced its decision to retire the 130-year-old Aunt Jemima brand due to its origins in racist imagery, with the image of a black woman to be removed from products and a new name to follow. The company stated that while efforts had been made to update the brand, the changes were insufficient to address its racial stereotype. PepsiCo also committed to donating $5 million over five years to support the black community, building on a prior $400 million initiative.

title: Aunt Jemima to Get New Name as PepsiCo Concedes ‘Racial Stereotype’
summary: PepsiCo announced plans to change the name and packaging of its 131-year-old Aunt Jemima brand, acknowledging its roots in racial stereotypes. This decision by the Quaker Oats unit comes amidst nationwide protests for racial equality. Other brands like Uncle Ben's and Mrs. Butterworth's may also undergo similar changes.

title: Aunt Jemima logo dropped, Uncle Ben's under review as brands confront racial stereotypes
summary: PepsiCo Inc. announced it would change the name and brand image of its Aunt Jemima pancake mix and syrup, acknowledging the mascot's racist history. Separately, Mars Inc. is evaluating similar changes to its Uncle Ben's brand of packaged rice. These moves come amid widespread protests over racism sparked by George Floyd's death, prompting companies to address racial stereotypes embedded in their brands.

title: PepsiCo Appoints New APAC CEO from Walmart China
summary: PepsiCo has appointed Wern-Yuen Tan, formerly of Walmart China, as its new CEO of Asia Pacific, Australia, New Zealand, and China (APAC), effective June 15, 2020. Tan will be responsible for overseeing all of PepsiCo's operations in the region, bringing extensive experience in retail, food service, and consulting. Ram Krishnan, the previous APAC CEO, will transition full-time to his role as global chief commercial officer of PepsiCo.

title: Pepsico starts work on $16.2 million Old Post Office renovation for relocated corporate offices
summary: Pepsico Global Real Estate, Inc. is investing $16.2 million to renovate office space at Chicago's Old Post Office for its relocated corporate offices. This project will facilitate the move of 1,300 employees and consolidate operations from 412,000 sq. ft. to 192,000 sq. ft. on a single floor, with completion expected by winter. The new open layout is designed to foster collaboration and innovation for brands like Gatorade, Quaker, and Tropicana.

title: Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Bacardí y otras empresas forman alianza para subsistir en la pandemia
summary: Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, Kellog's, Mars, and Mondel formed an alliance to support neighborhood stores and maintain economic activity during the COVID-19 pandemic. This collaboration extends to logistical support, with Coca-Cola's trucks delivering sanitizing solutions produced by companies like Bacardí and José Cuervo, who shifted operations from beverages due to the crisis. The initiative aims to help small businesses adapt to new sanitary measures and ensure a steady supply of essential goods.

title: The Soviet Union Paid Pepsi With Vodka and Warships in Decades-Long Barter
summary: This article details the unusual decades-long business relationship between PepsiCo and the Soviet Union, which began in 1959 with a handshake deal facilitated by Richard Nixon. Due to the non-convertibility of the ruble, PepsiCo initially received Stolichnaya vodka as payment, and later, an astounding agreement involved PepsiCo accepting Soviet warships, briefly making them the "6th largest military in the world." The partnership highlights a unique chapter in Cold War-era commerce.

title: PepsiCo agrees to acquire Bare Snacks
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has announced its agreement to acquire Bare Foods Co. (Bare Snacks), a U.S.-based maker of baked fruit and vegetable snacks, for an undisclosed amount. This acquisition expands PepsiCo's snacking portfolio and aligns with its "Performance with Purpose" vision for healthier options. Bare Snacks will continue to operate independently from San Francisco, reporting to Frito-Lay North America.

title: Hershey Company pledges to end deforestation as part of its supply chain
summary: The Hershey Company has committed to ending deforestation in its global cocoa supply chain by stopping new deforestation and promoting agroforestry. This initiative involves not sourcing cocoa from areas with recent deforestation and implementing tree planting programs. Hershey will work with organizations like the World Cocoa Foundation and plans to release a comprehensive forestry plan by the end of 2018 to achieve its goals.

title: Pepsico launches direct-to-consumer website Snacks.com amid COVID-19 pandemic
summary: Amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, PepsiCo has launched two new direct-to-consumer websites, Snacks.com and PantryShop.com, to meet the increasing online demand for food and beverages. Snacks.com offers over 100 Frito-Lay products, while PantryShop.com provides curated bundles of PepsiCo's top-selling pantry items. Both platforms were developed quickly to provide consumers with easy and fast access to their favorite products, with options for gifting and fast delivery.

title: PepsiCo launches direct-to-consumer sites for its brands
summary: PepsiCo has launched two new direct-to-consumer websites, PantryShop.com and Snacks.com, to allow consumers to order their favorite brands directly. This move aims to meet consumer needs, especially with increased at-home consumption during the coronavirus pandemic, and was developed in-house within 30 days. The sites offer bundled products and individual snacks with shipping options, and industry experts predict other CPG companies may follow suit, though some caution about the logistical challenges and impact on retailer relationships.

title: Why PepsiCo launched 2 new direct-to-consumer sites
summary: PepsiCo launched two new direct-to-consumer websites, PantryShop.com and Snacks.com, to offer specialized bundles and a wide selection of Frito-Lay products directly to consumers. This move responds to amplified e-commerce trends during the pandemic, allowing PepsiCo to meet consumers' changing shopping habits and potentially influence in-store product displays. The initiative aims to provide consumers with more choices and convenience, despite direct-to-consumer not traditionally being a major revenue source for large CPG companies.

title: Private investors buy Radio Systems Corporation, but company will stay in Knoxville
summary: Radio Systems Corporation, founded by Randy Boyd, has been acquired by international private investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice (CD&R). Despite the buyout, the pet product company will remain headquartered in Knoxville, a key factor in the sale. John Compton of CD&R will become chairman of Radio System Corporation's board, and Randy Boyd will continue to serve on the board.

title: Campbell Soup releases 2030 sustainable packaging goals
summary: Campbell Soup Co. announced new goals to reduce packaging waste by 2030, aiming for 100% recyclable or industrially compostable packaging. The initiatives include increasing post-consumer recycled content, adding on-pack labeling by 2022, and collaborating to improve recycling infrastructure. This builds on previous efforts to make packaging more sustainable.

title: PepsiCo Foodservice Launches Four New Initiatives To Support Restaurant Industry COVID-19 Relief Efforts
summary: PepsiCo Foodservice has launched four new initiatives to support the restaurant industry and its workers, who have been severely impacted by COVID-19, building on the company's prior $50 million commitment. These programs include fundraising for the Restaurant Employee Relief Fund, promoting The Great American Takeout, offering resources for restaurants on PepsiCoPartners.com, and continuing various relief efforts like donations to healthcare workers and "Drinks On Us" promotions. The efforts aim to provide financial aid, encourage consumer support for local eateries, and assist businesses in navigating the new landscape.

title: PepsiCo Opens Two New eCommerce Outlets
summary: PepsiCo has launched two new direct-to-consumer websites, PantryShop.com and Snacks.com, to meet increased demand for food and beverage products amid the ongoing pandemic. These platforms offer curated "pantry kits" and a wide selection of snack products, enabling shoppers to order from home with convenient shipping options. The initiative underscores PepsiCo's focus on e-commerce and digital capabilities to meet evolving consumer needs.

title: Flavors for dairy applications offer endless possibilities
summary: The dairy industry is seeing a boom in flavor innovation, moving beyond traditional vanilla and chocolate to embrace savory, international, and floral options. While sweet flavors still dominate, there's a growing demand for options that align with health and wellness trends, including natural, clean-label ingredients and reduced sugar. Flavor companies are responding with new technologies and services to help dairy processors meet evolving consumer preferences and market demands.

title: PepsiCo Beats on Earnings but Trades Under Death Cross
summary: PepsiCo (PEP) beat bottom-line estimates but its stock is trading below key technical levels, including its semiannual and quarterly pivots, and is in "death cross" territory. Despite beating EPS estimates for five consecutive quarters and offering a favorable dividend yield, the stock's price movements indicate significant volatility and potential for further downside. Investors are advised to buy on weakness to the 200-week SMA and reduce holdings at higher risky levels.

title: How is Coca-Cola dealing with the coronavirus crisis?
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey discusses the company's strategy for navigating the coronavirus crisis, emphasizing flexibility, long-term vision, and adapting to sharp changes in consumption habits, particularly the decline in away-from-home channels and a predicted "seismic shift" to e-commerce. The company is observing China for insights into recovery phases, implementing employee redeployment, and managing its global supply chain to avoid major disruptions despite border challenges.

title: BJ’s Wholesale Club Holdings, Inc. Appoints Paul Cichocki as Executive Vice President, Membership, Analytics, and Business Transformation
summary: BJ’s Wholesale Club has appointed Paul Cichocki as its new Executive Vice President of Membership, Analytics, and Business Transformation. In this role, he will oversee the company's membership, marketing, and analytics organizations, reporting directly to President and CEO Lee Delaney. Cichocki brings over 23 years of experience, including his previous role as a partner at Bain & Company, focusing on performance improvement and business transformation in various industries.

title: BJ’s Wholesale Club Holdings, Inc. Appoints Paul Cichocki as Executive Vice President, Membership, Analytics, and Business Transformation
summary: BJ’s Wholesale Club has appointed Paul Cichocki as its new Executive Vice President of Membership, Analytics, and Business Transformation, effective April 1, 2020. Cichocki will oversee membership, marketing, and analytics, reporting to BJ's President and CEO Lee Delaney. He previously served as a partner at Bain & Company, bringing extensive experience in performance improvement and business transformation to the role.

title: PepsiCo commits more than $45M to coronavirus food, PPE initiatives
summary: PepsiCo announced a global initiative committing over $45 million to support communities affected by the coronavirus pandemic. The funding will provide protective gear for healthcare workers, testing services, and distribute more than 50 million nutritious meals worldwide. This effort is part of a broader corporate response to the ongoing crisis, leveraging PepsiCo's resources to aid the most vulnerable.

title: ADM commits $1 million to fight COVID-19 pandemic
summary: Archer Daniels Midland Co. (ADM) has pledged $1 million to combat the spread of COVID-19, supporting the World Health Organization, local charities, and matching employee contributions. The company's chairman and CEO, Juan Luciano, emphasized ADM's commitment to employee safety, community support, and maintaining agricultural supply chain continuity. Other companies like Cargill and MGP Ingredients are also contributing to the fight against the pandemic.

title: PepsiCo, Mondelez, Smucker Announce Enhanced Employee Benefits Amid Virus
summary: Major food producers and distributors like Mondelēz, J.M. Smucker, PepsiCo, and United Natural Foods have announced enhanced employee benefits in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. These benefits include pay raises, bonuses, paid leave, hardship awards, and expanded hiring to support their workforce and ensure the continuity of the food supply chain. Companies are also making significant donations to address food instability and emergency relief efforts.

title: PepsiCo To Provide Enhanced Benefits To All U.S. Employees And Additional Compensation To U.S. Frontline During Unprecedented Health Pandemic
summary: PepsiCo announced enhanced benefits for all U.S. employees and additional compensation for over 90,000 frontline workers, including an extra $100 per week for full-time employees, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. The company also plans to hire 6,000 new full-time, full-benefit frontline employees and the PepsiCo Foundation is investing up to $11 million in community support initiatives. These measures aim to support employees and communities during the unprecedented health crisis, ensuring the continued supply of food and beverages.

title: 4 Reasons Not to Sell Keurig Dr Pepper Stock
summary: This article provides four reasons why investors should not sell Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) stock despite market downturns. The reasons include the company's market-beating performance, profitable merger synergies, diversified product portfolio, and healthy dividend. It emphasizes that KDP offers both value and growth potential, making it a compelling hold for long-term investors.

title: PepsiCo Expands Energy Drink Portfolio With Rockstar Acquisition
summary: PepsiCo Inc. is set to acquire Rockstar Energy Beverages for $3.85 billion, significantly expanding its presence in the energy drink market. This acquisition follows a decade-long distribution agreement between the two companies in North America. PepsiCo expects the deal to accelerate Rockstar's growth and enhance its own position in the functional beverage category.

title: Microsoft announces change to its board of directors
summary: Microsoft Corporation announced that Co-Founder and Technology Advisor Bill Gates stepped down from its Board of Directors to focus on philanthropic priorities. He will continue to serve as a Technology Advisor to CEO Satya Nadella and other leaders. The board will now consist of 12 members.

title: PepsiCo is buying Rockstar energy drink maker for $3.85 billion
summary: PepsiCo announced its acquisition of Rockstar Inc., the energy drink maker, for $3.85 billion to expand its beverage range amidst declining soda sales. This strategic move, led by CEO Ramon Laguarta, aims to capture a larger share of the fast-growing energy drink market, a segment where PepsiCo and Coca-Cola have previously had weaker presences. The deal also includes an additional $700 million in payments for future tax benefits and is expected to close in the first half of 2020.

title: Pepsi enters energy drink market with $3.85bn Rockstar deal
summary: PepsiCo has acquired Rockstar Energy Beverages for $3.85 billion to enter the growing energy drink market and diversify its offerings. This move positions PepsiCo to compete directly with Coca-Cola, which has a stake in Monster, and builds on an existing distribution deal between Pepsi and Rockstar since 2009. The acquisition is a significant strategic step for PepsiCo amidst market volatility and its shares were down slightly in pre-market trading following the announcement.

title: PepsiCo Agrees to Buy Energy-Drink Maker
summary: PepsiCo has agreed to acquire Rockstar Energy Beverages for $3.85 billion to expand its presence in the growing energy-drink market. This move will solidify PepsiCo's position as a major player in the energy drink category, building on its existing distribution partnership with Rockstar in North America since 2009.

title: PepsiCo Agrees to Buy Energy-Drink Maker
summary: PepsiCo has agreed to acquire Rockstar Energy Beverages for $3.85 billion to expand its presence in the growing energy-drink market. This acquisition will bring Rockstar, which PepsiCo has distributed in North America since 2009, fully under the beverage giant's ownership. The deal was confirmed by both companies on Wednesday.

title: Global Functional Drinks Market 2020-2024 | Evolving Opportunities with Archer Daniels Midland Co. and Danone SA | Technavio
summary: The global functional drinks market is projected to grow by USD 179.28 billion during 2020-2024, at a CAGR of over 11%. This growth is primarily driven by the health benefits offered by functional drinks and increasing consumption among millennials. Key companies in the market include Archer Daniels Midland Co., Danone SA, Monster Beverage Corp., Nestlé SA, and NextFoods Inc.

title: PepsiCo aims for energy boost with $3.85 billion Rockstar deal
summary: PepsiCo announced a $3.85 billion deal to acquire Rockstar Energy Beverages, significantly expanding its presence in the energy drink market. This move is part of CEO Ramon Laguarta's strategy to diversify away from sugary drinks and salty snacks and intensify competition with Coca-Cola in the growing energy beverage sector. The acquisition is expected to give PepsiCo a broader portfolio of energy drinks, though it is not expected to impact its revenue or EPS in 2020.

title: PepsiCo (PEP) to Buy Rockstar Energy Drinks for $3.85 Billion
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has agreed to acquire Rockstar Inc., the energy-drink maker, for $3.85 billion. This strategic move aims to expand PepsiCo's beverage range amidst declining soda consumption and marks one of the first major actions by CEO Ramon Laguarta. Pepsi and Rockstar have maintained a distribution agreement in North America since 2009.

title: PepsiCo to buy Rockstar Energy for $3.8 billion
summary: PepsiCo announced Wednesday a deal to acquire Rockstar Energy Beverages for $3.85 billion to expand its presence in the growing energy drink market. The acquisition is expected to close in the first half of this year and will complement PepsiCo's existing energy drink portfolio, including Mountain Dew's Kickstart, GameFuel, and AMP brands. Despite Rockstar drinks having been distributed by PepsiCo in North America since 2009, this acquisition allows PepsiCo greater flexibility and growth opportunities in the category.

title: PepsiCo nears $3.85B deal for energy-drink maker Rockstar
summary: PepsiCo is reportedly nearing a $3.85 billion deal to acquire Rockstar Energy Beverages, a move that would significantly expand PepsiCo's presence in the growing energy-drink market. This potential acquisition would mark the first major strategic move under CEO Ramon Laguarta and address a weak spot for PepsiCo in the energy-drink category. The deal would also allow PepsiCo to expand its own energy drink brands and Rockstar's distribution, avoiding legal issues similar to those faced by rival Coca-Cola.

title: PepsiCo targets online snacks growth in China with definitive agreement to acquire Be & Cheery
summary: PepsiCo has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Hangzhou Haomusi Food Co., Ltd. (“Be & Cheery”), a leading online snacks company in China, for US $705 million. This acquisition aims to accelerate PepsiCo's growth in China by leveraging Be & Cheery's strong e-commerce presence, diverse product portfolio, and data-led innovation capabilities. The transaction is subject to Haoxiangni shareholder vote and regulatory approvals, marking an important step in PepsiCo's goal to become a leading consumer-centric food and beverage company in China.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper and Nestle partner on Starbucks K-Cup pods
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper, Inc. has partnered with Nestlé USA to manufacture and distribute Starbucks-branded packaged coffee in K-Cup pods in the U.S. and Canada. This agreement replaces KDP's existing K-Cup pod agreement with Starbucks Corp. following a transition period, with financial terms undisclosed. Nestle Coffee Partners President Tony Matta expressed excitement about accelerating growth for the Starbucks brand on the Keurig K-Cup platform.

title: Starbucks to launch Beyond Meat breakfast sandwich in Canada
summary: Starbucks is introducing a Beyond Meat cheddar and egg breakfast sandwich at approximately 1,200 locations in Canada starting March 3, making it the coffee chain's first meat alternative item. This launch follows an earlier announcement by Starbucks' COO Rosalind Brewer about the company's plans to introduce a plant-based breakfast item in both the U.S. and Canada in 2020. The Beyond Meat offering will be a permanent part of Starbucks' core menu, unlike similar trials by other chains in Canada.

title: Starbucks unveils R.-T.-D. nitro cold brew
summary: Starbucks has introduced a ready-to-drink (R.-T.-D.) nitro cold brew, now available nationwide in grocery stores and Starbucks locations. The new beverages come in black, dark caramel, and vanilla sweet cream flavors, packaged in 9.6-oz cans designed to deliver a smooth taste. This launch is a result of the ongoing collaboration between Starbucks and PepsiCo through the North American Coffee Partnership, which first launched cold brew in Starbucks restaurants in 2016.

title: Breaking! PepsiCo Adopts A Comprehensive New Policy For Sourcing Palm Oil After Addressing Deforestation & Human Rights Violations
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has announced a new comprehensive palm oil sourcing policy aimed at eliminating deforestation, peatland destruction, and human and labor rights abuses from its supply chain. This move follows a six-year public campaign and positions PepsiCo as a leader in responsible palm oil production. The policy also includes a critical change to apply to suppliers at a group level, extending its reach to the entire operations of suppliers, including joint ventures like Indofood, and commits to improved human rights provisions.

title: PepsiCo’s Pure Leaf tea subverts classic fairy tales with Amy Poehler
summary: Pure Leaf, the iced tea brand owned by PepsiCo and Unilever's Lipton, has launched an integrated marketing campaign titled "No Is Beautiful," featuring actress Amy Poehler. The campaign encourages people, particularly women, to say "no" to things that don't matter to make time for what does, using a digital content series where Poehler reworks classic fairy tales. This marketing push aims to position Pure Leaf as a purpose-led brand ahead of new product launches.

title: PepsiCo to buy online snacks retailer in China
summary: PepsiCo Inc. is set to acquire Chinese online snacks retailer Hangzhou Haomusi Food Co. (Be & Cheery) for $705 million, expanding its presence in the Chinese market. This strategic move aims to capitalize on PepsiCo's double-digit revenue growth in Asia, despite a global decline in sugary soft drink consumption and a recent shortfall in its 2020 earnings forecast. The acquisition signifies PepsiCo's long-term commitment to China, even amidst the challenges posed by the coronavirus outbreak.

title: PepsiCo buys Chinese snack brand Be & Cheery for $705M
summary: PepsiCo has acquired the Chinese snack brand Be & Cheery for $705 million from Haoxiangni Health Food Co Ltd. This strategic move aims to strengthen PepsiCo's position in China's growing e-commerce snack market and leverage Be & Cheery's direct-to-consumer capabilities. Be & Cheery, founded in 2003, reported revenues of approximately 5 billion yuan in 2019.

title: PepsiCo, Verizon Back Battery-Free Sensor Startup Wiliot
summary: Wiliot, a semiconductor startup specializing in battery-free Bluetooth-enabled sensors that harness energy from radio waves, has secured an additional $20 million in Series B funding. This investment, with participation from PepsiCo Inc., Verizon Ventures, and others, brings their total Series B round to $50 million. Wiliot, founded by the creators of Wilocity Ltd., aims to revolutionize IoT devices by replacing traditional batteries and wired electricity.

title: PepsiCo beats quarterly expectations on healthy snacks, soda, Gatorade
summary: PepsiCo Inc. exceeded analyst expectations for its quarterly revenue and profit, driven by strong demand for its healthy snacks, sodas, and Gatorade energy drinks. The company reported a 5.7% increase in net revenue to $20.64 billion for the fourth quarter, surpassing estimates. This growth was fueled by double-digit net revenue growth in premium brands and increased sales across North American beverages and Frito-Lay snacks.

title: Kraft Heinz and Pepsi Closed Chinese Plants On Coronavirus
summary: Kraft Heinz CEO Miguel Patricio announced the closure of some of its China plants due to the coronavirus outbreak, with PepsiCo also closing one facility. While China accounts for only 2% of Kraft Heinz's sales, the company sources raw materials from suppliers importing from the region, leading Patricio to suggest finding alternative supplies due to disruptions.

title: EXHIBIT 99.1
summary: Griffin Capital Essential Asset REIT has acquired an industrial property in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, for $34.9 million. The 526,320-square-foot facility is fully occupied by Pepsi Bottling Ventures, serving as a distribution center for PepsiCo products and a production facility for Aquafina water. This acquisition, part of a 1031 exchange, aligns with the REIT's strategy for long-term value and cash flow.

title: Unilever considering sale of tea business as sales turn downward
summary: Unilever P.L.C. is reviewing its global tea business, including brands like Lipton and PG Tips, due to declining sales of traditional black tea. The company is considering all options, including a full or partial sale, as consumers shift towards herbal teas and coffee, especially in developed markets. This follows previous acquisitions such as Tazo and Pukka Herbs to strengthen its position in the herbal tea segment.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper acquires sparkling water brand Limitless
summary: Keurig Dr Pepper has acquired Limitless, a Chicago-based caffeinated sparkling water brand, for an undisclosed sum. This strategic move aims to expand Limitless's distribution, primarily found in Walmart, and strengthen Keurig Dr Pepper's water portfolio, particularly in the growing market for caffeinated beverages. The acquisition highlights Keurig Dr Pepper's focus on trending drinks like sparkling water to adapt to changing consumer demands and streamline its product offerings.

title: FranklinCovey wants to change the culture of Corporate Pakistan. Will it?
summary: FranklinCovey, a global consulting and training organization, is actively working to change corporate culture in Pakistan by focusing on human resource development and the principles from "7 Habits of Highly Effective People." Through its General Manager International Partners, Steve Fitzgerald, and the all-female leadership of FranklinCovey Pakistan, the company aims to help Pakistani businesses address challenges like unmotivated workforces and cultural inefficiencies, particularly among new hires. The article explores whether their methods, which emphasize common sense and systematic culture building, can truly transform deeply ingrained corporate practices in Pakistan.

title: Conagra Brands sets sustainable packaging goal
summary: Conagra Brands, Inc. announced a goal to convert all its plastic packaging to renewable, recyclable, or compostable materials by 2025. This initiative is part of a broader environmental sustainability effort, which has already seen significant plastic reductions through projects like Healthy Choice Power Bowls made from plant-based materials. Conagra also plans to educate consumers on proper packaging disposal and joins other major food companies like Nestle and Kellogg in setting ambitious sustainable packaging targets.

title: PepsiCo moves to 100% renewable electricity in U.S.
summary: PepsiCo has announced that its U.S. operations will use 100% renewable electricity starting this year. This move is part of the company's broader goal to reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions by 20% by 2030, and is estimated to eliminate half a million metric tons of annual emissions. The company is achieving this through a mix of on-site renewable energy, virtual power-purchase agreements, and renewable-energy certificates.

title: PepsiCo, Monster Beverage Corp slowed CBD talks after FDA intervention – report
summary: PepsiCo and Monster Beverage Corp reportedly paused their work on CBD-infused beverages due to the US authorities' inability to guarantee the ingredient's safety. This decision followed intervention from the FDA which has yet to approve CBD as a dietary supplement or food additive. The news suggests a cautious approach by major beverage companies regarding CBD products without clear regulatory guidance.

title: How Coke and Pepsi compare when it comes to social media
summary: This article compares Coca-Cola ($KO) and Pepsi ($PEP) based on their social media presence, specifically Facebook and Instagram likes, rather than traditional financial metrics. It highlights Coca-Cola's significantly larger following on these platforms, suggesting that its brand resonates more strongly online. The analysis also briefly mentions UBS's positive outlook on Coca-Cola's stock due to stable earnings growth and innovation.

title: Billionaire Ken Langone And Group of Investors Partners With La Tortillería and Abasto Media
summary: Billionaire Ken Langone and a group of prominent investors have formed a strategic alliance with La Tortillería, a leading Hispanic food distributor, and its sister company Abasto Media. This partnership is expected to accelerate the business growth of both companies, particularly in the Hispanic food market. The investors, including co-founder of Home Depot Ken Langone and former PepsiCo North America CEO Al Carey, expressed confidence in the Calhoun brothers' management and the significant growth potential within the Hispanic market.
source: Abasto, Food and Beverage Industry News
source_domain: Abasto, Food and Beverage Industry News

title: Diet Dr Pepper doesn’t make false weight loss promises, court rules
summary: A U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Dr Pepper Snapple Group did not mislead consumers into believing Diet Dr Pepper promises weight loss or healthy weight management, upholding that the use of "diet" on labels does not constitute false advertising. This decision is consistent with previous rulings against PepsiCo and Coca-Cola in similar lawsuits, reinforcing that "diet" denotes fewer calories rather than health benefits. The ruling may deter future lawsuits unless plaintiffs can present stronger legal arguments, while beverage manufacturers are increasingly shifting away from artificial sweeteners and the term "diet."

title: PepsiCo Boss Donald Kendall, Who Started the Cola Wars, Has Died
summary: Donald M. Kendall, the former CEO of PepsiCo Inc., who built the company into a snack-and-beverage giant and initiated the "cola wars" with Coca-Cola, has died at 99. Kendall served as CEO from 1963 to 1986, during which sales grew nearly 40-fold and he introduced Pepsi to the Soviet Union. He famously launched the "Pepsi Challenge" marketing campaign against rival Coca-Cola.

title: Diet Dr Pepper does not promise weight loss or deceive consumers - U.S. appeals court
summary: A U.S. federal appeals court ruled that Diet Dr Pepper does not deceive consumers by using "diet" in its name, stating that reasonable consumers understand it refers to calorie content rather than promising weight loss. This decision could impact similar lawsuits against other diet soft drink manufacturers, reinforcing that the term "diet" is understood as a relative claim.
banner_image: FILE PHOTO: Dr Pepper soda cans for sale are pictured at a grocery store in Pasadena, California, U.S., February 14, 2018. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni

title: Where Is The Headquarters Of Pepsi?
summary: PepsiCo's headquarters has been located in Purchase, New York, since 1970, in a campus featuring the Donald M. Kendall Sculpture Garden. Prior to this, it was in Manhattan, New York City. The article details the architecture of the headquarters designed by Edward Durell Stone and the history of the surrounding towns of Harrison and Purchase, New York.

title: Pepsi to Sell Coffee-Cola Drink That Has Twice as Much Caffeine
summary: PepsiCo Inc. announced plans to launch Pepsi Cafe in the U.S. in April. This new beverage blends coffee and cola flavors and contains nearly double the caffeine of a regular Pepsi. It will be available in original and vanilla flavors, offering consumers a new caffeinated option.

title: Understanding PepsiCo’s Business Segments and More
summary: This article provides an in-depth look at PepsiCo's business segments, its product portfolio across beverages and snacks, and its financial performance. It highlights PepsiCo's strategy to address declining carbonated soft drink volumes by expanding into healthier options and international markets, while comparing its performance and strategies with competitors like Coca-Cola and Mondelez International. The article also details the profitability of its snack food business versus its beverage business and the importance of branding and productivity initiatives.

title: Pepsi to sell coffee-cola drink that has twice as much caffeine
summary: PepsiCo Inc. is launching Pepsi Cafe in April, a new coffee-cola blend with nearly double the caffeine of a regular Pepsi, available in original and vanilla flavors. This move responds to changing beverage preferences and increasing competition in the market. Rival Coca-Cola Co. is also expanding its presence in the canned coffee market after acquiring Costa.

title: Coca-Cola CEO says the beverage giant waited too long to make a sparkling water brand
summary: Coca-Cola CEO James Quincey admitted that the company waited too long to launch a dedicated sparkling water brand, despite the growing popularity of the category. Coca-Cola is set to launch its new sparkling water brand, AHA, on March 2 in the United States, aiming to compete with rivals like PepsiCo's Bubly and National Beverage's LaCroix. This launch marks Coca-Cola's first new brand in over a decade, though it has previously ventured into the sparkling water market with Dasani and Smartwater variations, and the acquisition of Topo Chico.

title: Company of the Year: PepsiCo
summary: CFO Dive recognized PepsiCo as Company of the Year for its long-standing integrity and its finance organization's strategic approach, a philosophy championed by former CFO and CEO Indra Nooyi. The article highlights PepsiCo's role as a training ground for strategic CFOs and its consistent ethical posture, influencing top finance talent across various industries. Former PepsiCo executives are highly sought after for top CFO positions due to their comprehensive experience in operational finance and strategic partnerships.

title: 5 Best Consumer Staples Stocks to Buy Now for 2020
summary: This article identifies five top consumer staples stocks for 2020, emphasizing their dividend yields and defensive qualities in a volatile market. It discusses how to evaluate these stocks, including payout ratios and balance sheet health, and highlights two ETFs for diversification before diving into specific stock recommendations. The author suggests consumer staples are good long-term investments, especially with current interest rate trends.

title: PepsiCo buys PopCorners maker BFY Brands
summary: PepsiCo announced its acquisition of PopCorners maker BFY Brands, aiming to strengthen its presence in healthier snack options and align with its "Winning with Purpose" initiative. The deal will place PopCorners, along with Flourish Veggie Crisps and Flex Protein Crisps, under Frito-Lay North America, expanding PepsiCo's portfolio of better-for-you snacks. This acquisition follows PepsiCo's strategic shift in corporate structure and previous investments in healthy snack brands like Bare Snacks and Health Warrior.

title: Pepsico expands Better-For-You snacks portfolio by acquisition of BFY Brands
summary: Pepsico announced its acquisition of BFY Brands, known for PopCorners and other better-for-you snacks, from the Permira funds. This strategic move aims to expand Frito-Lay North America's snacking portfolio with more nutritious options and leverage PepsiCo's distribution platform for accelerated growth. BFY Brands will continue its operations with current leadership, maintaining its manufacturing facilities and expansion plans.

title: PepsiCo Announces Definitive Agreement to Acquire BFY Brands Expanding Better-For-You Portfolio and Production Capabilities
summary: PepsiCo announced it has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire BFY Brands, the maker of PopCorners snacks, which will report into PepsiCo's Frito-Lay North America division. This acquisition expands Frito-Lay's snacking portfolio with more nutritious options and enhances PepsiCo's production capabilities. The transaction is subject to customary conditions and regulatory approvals.

title: Campbell's Wants to Make Canned Soup a Hot Commodity Again
summary: Campbell Soup Company is striving to revitalize its canned soup business as consumer preferences shift away from processed foods. New CEO Mark Clouse believes in the potential of "fabric-of-the-nation" brands and is focused on changing the company's orientation rather than the core products themselves. Despite challenges from changing tastes, a fragmented media landscape, and competitors, Campbell's recently saw an increase in its soup market share.

title: Carnival Cruise Line Selects PepsiCo as Preferred Beverage Partner
summary: Carnival Cruise Line has chosen PepsiCo as its preferred beverage partner for its North American fleet, with the transition beginning in January 2020. This partnership will offer Carnival guests a wide variety of PepsiCo beverages, including brands like Starbucks ready-to-drink coffee and bubly sparkling water. Both companies express excitement about providing more beverage choices to guests and collaborating on sustainability efforts.

title: Coca-Cola’s Aha moment: New sparkling water brand debuts in March
summary: Coca-Cola is launching a new sparkling water brand called Aha in March 2020, marking its first major new brand launch since 2006. Aha will replace Dasani's sparkling water in retail and features eight unique flavor combinations, including two with 30 mg of caffeine. This move aims to innovate in the rapidly growing sparkling water market, where Coca-Cola faces stiff competition and seeks to differentiate from existing brands like LaCroix and PepsiCo's bubly.

title: The latest sign we’re in a sparkling water bubble: Coca-Cola is making something called Aha
summary: Coca-Cola announced its biggest brand launch in a decade with a new flavored seltzer line called "Aha," set to debut in March 2020. This move is aimed at competing with LaCroix and Pepsi's Bubly, with some flavors featuring caffeine to tap into another growing trend. The launch signifies the continued expansion in the sparkling water market amidst a perceived "bubble."

title: Lineage Logistics | Success Story
summary: Lineage Logistics, a company revolutionizing temperature-controlled supply chain and logistics, moved its international headquarters from Irvine, California, to Michigan in 2017. The decision was driven by Michigan's talent pipeline, optimal location to customers, and support from the MEDC, despite competing sites in other states. Since relocating, Lineage Logistics has exceeded its initial job creation promises and significantly boosted its revenue, partly due to its strategic investment in Michigan.

title: San Antonio-area company takes on Gatorade owner PepsiCo
summary: Alert Services Inc., a San Marcos-based distributor, is suing PepsiCo, owner of Gatorade, for over $1 million alleging breach of contract and deceptive trade practices. Alert Services claims PepsiCo terminated its 30-year contract without explanation in March, leading to allegations that Gatorade employees steered business to competitors in exchange for kickbacks. The loss of the Gatorade contract threatens to put Alert Services out of business.

title: PepsiCo Leaders Go 'Bananas' For Hakuna Brands Banana Nice Cream, Awards Founder Hannah Hong $100,000 As Inaugural Winner Of Stacy's Rise Project
summary: Hannah Hong, founder of Hakuna Brands, a banana-based non-dairy frozen dessert company, has been awarded $100,000 as the inaugural grand prize winner of the Stacy's Rise Project. This funding and mentorship program by PepsiCo and Frito-Lay supports female entrepreneurs in the food and beverage industry. Hong's win highlights the program's commitment to empowering women, especially with the timing around Women's Entrepreneurship Day.

title: Factbox: Meet McDonald's new CEO: Chris Kempczinski
summary: Chris Kempczinski has replaced Steve Easterbrook as CEO of McDonald's Corp after Easterbrook's dismissal due to a consensual relationship with an employee. Kempczinski, 51, joined McDonald's in 2015 as executive vice president and previously held roles at Procter & Gamble Co, PepsiCo Inc, and Kraft Foods. He holds an MBA from Harvard Business School and a bachelor's degree from Duke University, and was responsible for McDonald's U.S. operations before his promotion to CEO.

title: Coca-Cola Named The World’s Most Polluting Brand in Plastic Waste Audit
summary: A recent audit by Break Free From Plastic, involving 848 cleanup events across 51 countries, identified Coca-Cola as the largest plastic polluter globally. The audit collected over 475,000 pieces of plastic waste, with 11,732 items traced back to Coca-Cola. The article highlights the urgent need for smart consumer choices, efficient recycling infrastructure, and innovation in alternative materials to combat single-use plastic pollution.

title: PepsiCo Puts Military Veterans to Work
SodaStream to Offer Concentrates for Homemade Pepsi, Mountain Dew
summary: SodaStream announced it will soon offer concentrates for 10 of PepsiCo’s most popular soft drink brands, including Pepsi, 7 Up, and Mountain Dew, for at-home carbonation. While financial savings will be minimal, the primary benefit is expected to be a reduction in disposable plastic bottles. Initially launching in Sweden and Norway, distribution will expand to Germany and France in March 2020.

title: Hershey ties for top spot in food industry customer satisfaction index
summary: Hershey tied with Pepsi for the top spot in the 2019 American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI) for the food industry, both scoring 84 out of 100. Other major brands like Mars and Nestle saw slight decreases in their scores, while "All other brands" showed an increase, indicating a shift in consumer preferences towards smaller brands due to perceived value and competitive pricing. The report highlights the industry's strong quality and increasing customer perceptions of value, with technology expected to further improve satisfaction.

title: Economy on the right path, Hafeez Shaikh tells US investors
summary: Dr. Abdul Hafeez Shaikh, Adviser to the Prime Minister on Finance and Revenue, informed US investors that Pakistan's economy is stabilizing and encouraged them to expand their investments in the country. During his visit to the US for the IMF/WB annual meetings, Shaikh met with various financial institutions' representatives, including the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, Islamic Development Bank, and IFC, to discuss funding for Pakistan's development. He emphasized the government's efforts to improve the ease of doing business in Pakistan.

title: Leaked Audio Reveals How Coca-Cola Undermines Plastic Recycling Efforts
summary: Leaked audio from a recycling leaders' meeting reveals how Coca-Cola's philanthropic efforts were used to suppress discussions about effective recycling tools like bottle bills. The article details how Coca-Cola, despite being a major plastic polluter, has historically fought against legislation that would hold it accountable for plastic waste, instead funding organizations that shift responsibility to consumers. It highlights how this strategy continues globally, undermining genuine efforts to improve recycling rates and manage plastic pollution.

title: The Recycling Partnership and The PepsiCo Foundation Raise $25 Million for U.S. Recycling -- Reaching Funding Goal One Year into Five-Year Challenge
summary: The Recycling Partnership and The PepsiCo Foundation's "All In On Recycling" challenge has successfully raised $25 million in just over a year, significantly ahead of its five-year goal. This initiative aims to improve residential recycling for over 25 million U.S. families by investing in infrastructure, like curbside carts, and educational programs to combat "wishcycling." The funds are supporting efforts in several states, with plans to expand, and are expected to capture 55 million pounds of new recyclables annually and avoid 5.5 million tons of CO2.

title: BYD Places Yard Tractors With PepsiCo
summary: BYD Motors Inc. announced that three of its 8Y battery-electric yard trucks will be deployed at PepsiCo Inc.’s Modesto Frito-Lay facility as part of a state project. This initiative aims to showcase economically and environmentally sustainable warehousing and distribution technology through equipment testing and a one-year demonstration period. The project, funded by the California Air Resources Board, is led by the San Joaquin Air Pollution Control District and is expected to conclude in early 2021.

title: Pepsi’s $1 billion green bond puts it in growing ranks of big companies selling debt for climate-change initiatives
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has issued its first green bond, a $1 billion offering aimed at funding initiatives to reduce virgin-plastic use and replenish water consumption. This move positions Pepsi among a growing number of large companies utilizing debt for climate-change initiatives. The company also announced the appointment of Simon Lowden as its first chief sustainability officer, following a sustainability pact released in September.

title: PepsiCo: How the snack business steered the company away from rough waters
summary: This article examines how PepsiCo's Frito-Lay North America snack business has consistently driven growth and profitability, offsetting fluctuations in other segments. It details the division's revenue and operating profit growth from 2015 to 2018, highlighting product portfolio adjustments and market trends. The snack business is projected to continue its healthy growth, boosting PepsiCo's overall performance.

title: PepsiCo Kicks Off Month-Long Global Volunteering Event To Distribute More Than 1.1 Million Nutritious Meals For Those In Need & Support Local Communities
summary: PepsiCo announced the kickoff of its annual month-long global volunteering event, "PepsiCo Gives Back," aiming to distribute over 1.1 million nutritious meals to communities in need worldwide. Tens of thousands of employees will participate in meal packing events and local community support activities. This initiative builds on the PepsiCo Foundation's ongoing efforts to alleviate hunger and contribute to a sustainable food system globally.

title: PepsiCo Prices US$1 Billion Green Bond to Fund Key Sustainability Initiatives
summary: PepsiCo announced it has priced its first US$1 billion Green Bond to fund initiatives advancing its sustainability agenda, including sustainable plastics, decarbonization, and water sustainability. The company also named Simon Lowden as its first Chief Sustainability Officer to lead these efforts. The bond proceeds will support projects aligned with PepsiCo's sustainability priorities and U.N. Sustainable Development Goals.

title: PepsiCo’s 12% increase in ad spending fuels sales growth
summary: PepsiCo increased its advertising and marketing spending by 12% this year, contributing to higher sales across various brands and boosting market share for key brands. Net sales rose 4.3% to $17.2 billion in Q3, despite a 16% decrease in net income due to increased expenses. The company is also focusing on personalized marketing through consumer data, omnichannel retail, and initiatives to reach younger, socially conscious consumers.

title: Pepsi Says Higher Prices Haven’t Quenched Consumer Demand
summary: PepsiCo Inc. reported strong Q3 results, exceeding Wall Street estimates for sales and profit, driven by consumers' willingness to pay higher prices for its drinks and snacks. Despite concerns about a looming economic slowdown and weak manufacturing numbers, PepsiCo's CFO noted that U.S. consumers are doing well in terms of the company's business. The company expects to meet or exceed its full-year revenue growth thanks to strong performance across its divisions, including Frito-Lay and beverage units.

title: Frito-Lay Transforms California Production Site into First-of-its-Kind Showcase for Sustainability
summary: Frito-Lay is transforming its Modesto, California manufacturing site into an industry-leading showcase for environmentally sustainable manufacturing, warehousing, and distribution. This $30.8 million project aims to replace all diesel-powered freight equipment with zero-emission and near-zero emission technologies by 2021, supported by partnerships with the San Joaquin Valley Air Pollution Control District and funding from California Climate Investments. The initiative contributes to PepsiCo's goal of reducing absolute greenhouse gas emissions by 20 percent by 2030 and serves as a model for sustainable business practices across its facilities.

title: Retirees’ lawsuit against PepsiCo dismissed by federal judge
summary: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit brought by retirees against PepsiCo. The article indicates this legal outcome without providing further details on the reasons for dismissal or the specifics of the retirees' claims.

title: The Makers of Vita Coco & Lonely Whale Launch an Alternative to Single-Use Plastic Water Bottles
summary: Vita Coco and Lonely Whale partnered to launch "Ever & Ever," an aluminum-canned water as an eco-friendly alternative to single-use plastic water bottles. The initiative included the "Question How You Hydrate" campaign, a "Plastic Service Announcement" with celebrities, and a pop-up Museum of Plastic to raise awareness about plastic pollution and promote recycling aluminum. The campaign successfully generated significant impressions and led to Ever & Ever becoming the official water bottle of the United Nations, influencing larger competitors in the beverage industry.

title: Nestle, P&G say they will miss 2020 deforestation goals
summary: Nestle SA and Procter & Gamble Co have acknowledged they will not meet their 2020 goals to source ingredients that do not contribute to deforestation. Both companies, who made these pledges in 2010 at the urging of the Consumer Goods Forum, cite underestimation of demand and lax government regulations as reasons for falling short. Other major consumer goods companies have either declined to provide specifics on their deforestation goals or stated they will not make the 2020 zero deforestation pledges.

title: PepsiCo Releases 2018 Sustainability Report Highlighting Progress and A Renewed Focus To Help Build A More Sustainable Food System
summary: PepsiCo released its 2018 Sustainability Report, announcing a new purpose to help build a more sustainable food system as part of its "Winning with Purpose" vision. The report highlights progress and goals across six key areas: Agriculture, Water, Packaging, Products, Climate, and People. PepsiCo aims to reduce virgin plastic content, increase recycled content in packaging, achieve sustainable sourcing targets, and improve water-use efficiency while also committing to emission reductions and empowering women.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper-backed firm launches smart nutrition bottle
summary: LifeFuels, backed by Keurig Dr Pepper, has launched what it describes as the first smart nutrition bottle, integrating with an app to track hydration and nutrition goals. The product, while expensive at $180 for the bottle and $12 per FuelPod, aims to appeal to health-conscious consumers seeking natural flavors, portability, and data tracking capabilities, much like Fitbit revolutionized exercise tracking. This investment aligns with Keurig Dr Pepper's strategy to diversify its portfolio beyond coffee and soda, mirroring its successful single-serve coffee platform.

title: SMC folds packaging businesses in one entity
summary: San Miguel Corp. (SMC) is consolidating its packaging businesses under its subsidiary, San Miguel Yamamura Packaging Corp. (SMYPC), merging SMYPC and San Miguel Yamamura Asia Corp. (SMYAC) with SMYPC as the surviving entity. SMC will also increase its stake in SMYAC to 65 percent by acquiring an additional 5 percent. This move aims to streamline SMC's packaging operations, which serve a wide range of industries globally.

title: PepsiCo Accelerates Plastic Waste Reduction Efforts
summary: PepsiCo announced a new target to reduce 35% of virgin plastic content across its beverage portfolio by 2025, aiming to eliminate 2.5 million metric tons of cumulative virgin plastic. This initiative will be driven by increased use of recycled content, alternative packaging materials for brands like LIFEWTR, bubly, and Aquafina, and the expansion of its SodaStream business to avoid an estimated 67 billion plastic bottles. The company's sustainable plastics vision focuses on reducing plastic use, boosting recycling rates, and reinventing plastic packaging, building on existing goals to make 100% of its packaging recyclable, compostable, or biodegradable by 2025.

title: 5 ways Coca-Cola is cleaning up its plastic footprint in Africa
summary: Coca-Cola is implementing its "World Without Waste" vision in Africa to address plastic pollution. This involves creating a sustainable collection and recycling model (PETCO), designing better packaging for a circular economy, partnering across various sectors, making collection accessible through consumer education and school programs, and sharing expertise to find solutions. The goal is to collect and recycle the equivalent of every bottle or can sold by 2030 and use 100% recyclable packaging by 2025.

title: Food companies are banking on our urge to snack
summary: Food companies, despite a decline in processed food sales, are thriving in their snack divisions by marketing snacks as healthier. This trend has led companies like Campbell Soup Company, Hershey, PepsiCo, and Mars to acquire or invest in healthier snack brands, as consumers, particularly Gen Z and millennials, increasingly use snacks as meal replacements. The demand for "healthier" snacks is a growing source of revenue for the food industry.

title: Hasbro will phase out plastics from packaging — but not toys
summary: Hasbro Inc. announced plans to phase out plastic from its product packaging, including elastic bands and shrink wrap, starting in 2020 with a goal to virtually eliminate plastic from new product packaging by the end of 2022. While this initiative addresses consumer backlash against single-use plastics in packaging, the company has not yet committed to reducing plastic usage in the toys themselves. Chief Operating Officer John Frascotti indicated that plans for more sustainable materials in toys would be announced soon, though some packaging, like for Easy Bake Oven ingredients, will retain plastic due to health and regulatory requirements.

title: PepsiCo announces changes in bottled water packaging
summary: PepsiCo announced significant changes to its bottled water packaging, including LIFEWTR transitioning to 100% rPET bottles and bubly sparkling waters packaging no longer using plastic. The company's AQUAFINA brand will also introduce aluminum can packaging in U.S. foodservice outlets. These initiatives aim to eliminate thousands of metric tons of virgin plastic and greenhouse gas emissions, aligning with PepsiCo's sustainability goals for 2025.

title: Coca-Cola will sell Dasani in aluminum cans and bottles
summary: Coca-Cola is introducing Dasani in aluminum cans and bottles as part of a larger initiative to meet environmental goals and reduce plastic waste. The move includes new packaging, reduced plastic in existing bottles, and a hybrid bottle with recycled and plant-based materials. These changes aim to support Coca-Cola's environmental commitments and revitalize interest in its Dasani brand amid growing consumer concerns about plastic pollution.

title: UPS picks up Pepsico exec to be delivery giant's new CFO
summary: UPS has appointed Brian Newman, currently executive vice president of finance and operations for Latin America at PepsiCo, as its new CFO. Newman will assume the role on September 16. This move follows the recent retirement announcement of a groundbreaking UPS executive.

title: Yum! Brands names new CEO
summary: Yum! Brands Inc. has appointed David W. Gibbs as its new CEO, effective Jan. 1, 2020, succeeding Greg Creed, who is set to retire at the end of 2019. Gibbs currently serves as president and chief operating officer and has held various leadership roles since joining the company in 1989. Creed, who became CEO in January 2015, will remain in an advisory role and on the board to ensure a smooth transition.

title: Coca-Cola touts new packaging as part of Dasani's 'largest sustainability initiative' ever
summary: Coca-Cola is launching new recycled bottles and aluminum cans for its Dasani bottled water brand as part of its "largest sustainability initiative" ever. The aluminum cans will be available in the Northeastern U.S. later this year and nationwide in 2020, with new bottles following by mid-2020. This move continues Coca-Cola's environmental push, which has included previous efforts like launching "alcopop" in Japan and addressing animal abuse at a dairy supplier.

title: PepsiCo Executive to Become UPS Finance Chief
summary: United Parcel Service Inc. has appointed Brian Newman, a PepsiCo executive, as its new chief financial officer, effective September 16. Newman will succeed Richard Peretz, who is set to retire at the end of the year. This move comes as UPS aims to capitalize on the strained relationship between FedEx and Amazon and reflects a broader management strategy to bring in outside talent for change.

title: PepsiCo Announces Timing and Availability of Third Quarter Financial Results and Conference Call
summary: PepsiCo announced the timing and availability of its third-quarter financial results and a related conference call. The results for the quarter ending September 7 will be released on Thursday, October 3, 2019, at approximately 6:00 a.m. EDT. A webcast of the earnings conference call will follow at 7:45 a.m. EDT on the company's investor relations website.

title: The Secret History of Why Soda Companies Switched From Sugar to High-Fructose Corn Syrup
summary: This article uncovers the complex history behind soda companies' shift from sugar to high-fructose corn syrup (HFCS), attributing it not just to corn subsidies but significantly to political maneuvering by Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) and its CEO Dwayne Andreas. It details how Andreas championed sugar import quotas during the Reagan administration, artificially inflating domestic sugar prices and making HFCS the more economical sweetener for beverage giants like Coke and Pepsi. The piece explains that this strategic political intervention, rather than just market forces, solidified HFCS's dominance in the soda industry.

title: KKR devours Tim Tam biscuits maker in $2.2 billion deal with Campbell
summary: KKR & Co is buying Campbell Soup Co's Australian snacks unit, Arnott's, which includes popular biscuit brands like Tim Tam, in a deal reported to be worth $2.2 billion. This sale is part of Campbell's strategy to divest its international and "fresh" units under investor pressure to improve profitability. The acquisition gives KKR control of a brand synonymous with Australian snacking for over a century, positioning it for expansion in the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Inaugural "Stacy's Rise Project" Unveils Five Finalists, Kicks Off Executive Mentorship Phase of Program in Quest to Advance Female Food & Beverage Entrepreneurs
summary: The inaugural Stacy's Rise Project has announced its five finalists from over 400 applicants, aiming to advance female food and beverage entrepreneurs. Each finalist will receive a $20,000 grant and partake in a three-month executive mentorship program, with one ultimately winning a $100,000 grand prize. The project, supported by Frito-Lay and PepsiCo (NASDAQ: PEP), seeks to address the funding gap for female-founded businesses and promote an inclusive environment for business owners.

title: Coke Shares Hit All-Time High as New Drinks Win Customers
summary: Coca-Cola's shares reached an all-time high after the company reported strong second-quarter earnings and raised its full-year revenue expectations. This success is attributed to its product innovation, particularly low-sugar sodas and iced coffees, which now account for 25% of the company's revenue. CEO James Quincey highlighted significant growth opportunities in developing markets and noted the positive impact of beverages like Coca-Cola Plus Coffee and the acquisition of Costa Coffee.

title: Coca-Cola invests $20M in Health-Ade Kombucha
summary: The Coca-Cola Co. has made a $20 million equity investment in Health-Ade Kombucha, continuing its strategy to diversify beyond soda into healthier beverages. This move follows previous investments and aligns with other major food and beverage companies entering the kombucha market, despite legal challenges Health-Ade has faced regarding labeling. The investment is expected to support Health-Ade's innovation and expansion efforts.

title: PepsiCo Targets African Growth With Pioneer Foods Acquisition
summary: PepsiCo has agreed to acquire all outstanding shares of Pioneer Foods Group Ltd., a South African company, for approximately $1.7 billion. This acquisition aims to boost PepsiCo's expansion into Sub-Saharan Africa by leveraging Pioneer Foods' product portfolio and manufacturing capabilities. The deal will also enable PepsiCo to expand its Sustainable Farming Program in Africa and is expected to close by the first quarter of 2020.

title: Donald Knauss, Richard Smucker Honored by Grocery Manufacturers Assoc.
summary: Donald Knauss and Richard Smucker are being honored with the 2019 Hall of Achievement Award by the Grocery Manufacturers Association (GMA) for their significant contributions to the consumer packaged goods industry. Knauss previously served as chair and CEO of The Clorox Company, while Smucker was the CEO and co-CEO of The J.M. Smucker Company. The award will be presented at GMA’s annual Leadership Forum on August 15th.

title: Diet Coke revival helps boost Coca-Cola brand: Brand Finance rankings
summary: Coca-Cola's brand value increased by 19% to $36.2bn, largely due to the successful relaunch and rebranding of Diet Coke. Despite Pepsi's brand value decreasing, PepsiCo maintains a stronger overall portfolio due to its food brands and acquisitions like SodaStream. The article also highlights the challenges faced by soda brands with declining sales, health-conscious consumers, and sugar taxes, emphasizing the need for evolution to maintain market dominance.

title: From Hot Sauce to Pop Gloss, US Products Seep Into Iran
summary: Despite heightened political tensions and sanctions, American brands and products like Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Heinz, and Tabasco are widely available and popular in Iran. Young Iranians particularly embrace U.S. lifestyle and products, although many items are bottled locally or enter the country through indirect channels. This prevalence highlights a cultural divide between official rhetoric and popular consumer choices in Iran.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Always Coca-Cola: World’s Favourite Soda Tops Brand Ranking
summary: Coca-Cola has retained its title as the world's most valuable soft drink brand, with its brand value increasing by 19% to US$36.2 billion, while Pepsi's brand value decreased. Nestlé leads as the most valuable food brand and possesses the largest food & drink brand portfolio globally, surpassing US$70 billion. The report also highlights declines for corporate brands like Kraft, Unilever, and Heinz, significant growth for China's Yili in dairy, and Quaker as the fastest-growing food brand.

title: Earnings preview: What to expect when PepsiCo reports Q2 2019 results?
summary: PepsiCo (NASDAQ: PEP) is set to report its Q2 2019 earnings on July 9, with analysts projecting a 7.5% decline in earnings per share to $1.49 and a 2% increase in revenues to $16.4 billion. The company expects strong performance from its snacks business and some momentum in beverages, although weakness in Quaker Foods North America might impact topline growth. PepsiCo's shares have gained 19% year-to-date, driven by diversification efforts and growth in emerging markets.

title: Netflix's 'Stranger Things' revives New Coke. Here's how the failed soda cost Coca-Cola millions in 1985
summary: Netflix's "Stranger Things" is featuring New Coke in its third season, bringing back Coca-Cola's infamous 1985 marketing blunder. The original New Coke launch led to consumer boycotts and significant financial losses, including $4 million on research and marketing and $30 million in unsold inventory. Despite its failure, the New Coke fiasco is now seen as a cautionary business tale and ultimately reinvigorated consumer interest in Coca-Cola's classic formula.

title: PepsiCo to Switch From Plastic to Cans for Aquafina Water
summary: PepsiCo announced it will begin selling Aquafina water in aluminum cans next year, initially to partners like stadiums and restaurants, and experimenting in retail stores. This move is part of the company's broader sustainability efforts, including transitioning its Lifewatr brand to 100% recycled plastic and discontinuing plastic bottles for Bubly sparkling water, aiming to eliminate over 8,000 metric tons of virgin plastic. The decision comes amidst industry-wide pressure to reduce plastic waste, with aluminum cans offering better recyclability and a higher percentage of reused material compared to plastic.

title: Pepsi to Test Out Selling Water in Cans
summary: PepsiCo Inc. (PEP) is planning to test selling its Aquafina water in aluminum cans starting next year, amidst growing industry pressure against plastic. The beverage giant will offer the canned water to partners like stadiums and restaurants, and also try it out in some retail stores. This move is a direct response to the widespread backlash against plastic products.

title: Yum! Brands Names Chris Turner as Chief Financial Officer
summary: Yum! Brands Inc. announced that Chris Turner will join the company as Chief Financial Officer, effective August 8, 2019. Turner, previously from PepsiCo and McKinsey & Company, will be responsible for finance, corporate strategy, supply chain, and information technology. This appointment concludes the search for the top financial post, currently held by David Gibbs.

title: Yum! Brands Names PepsiCo’s Chris Turner CFO
summary: Yum! Brands, Inc. announced the appointment of Chris Turner, formerly of PepsiCo, as its new Chief Financial Officer, effective August 8. Turner will be responsible for finance, corporate strategy, supply chain, and information technology, bringing nearly 20 years of experience in strategy, finance, M&A, and operations leadership from his tenures at PepsiCo and McKinsey & Company. He is expected to play a critical role in driving global growth and maximizing value for the company's brands, franchisees, employees, and shareholders.

title: 3 Charts That Suggest It's Time to Buy Food and Beverage Stocks
summary: This article suggests that now is an opportune time to invest in food and beverage stocks, citing inelastic demand for basic necessities.
