summary: PepsiCo is launching "The Hive," a new incubator aimed at cultivating niche brands and venture products outside of its core headquarters. This move mirrors similar initiatives by other CPG companies as PepsiCo seeks innovation, particularly in healthy and unique food and beverage offerings, to combat slumping sales and growing competition from startups. The company hopes this strategy will help it identify and nurture new products without overpaying for acquisitions.

title: PepsiCo's beverage sales dip, but snack sales increase
summary: PepsiCo reported a dip in North American beverage sales volume in the second quarter despite efforts to introduce new drinks. However, higher sales from its Frito-Lay snack division helped to offset this weakness. The company's profit was impacted by a higher tax rate, though earnings per share exceeded Wall Street expectations.

title: These 11 Companies Control Everything About the Fourth of July
summary: This article examines the market concentration of goods commonly consumed on the Fourth of July, revealing how a small number of large corporations dominate various sectors from hot dogs and beer to condiments and charcoal. It highlights how these monopolistic tendencies impact consumers through potentially higher prices and limited choices, and discusses historical examples of corporations suppressing competition. The piece suggests that such market control contradicts the spirit of independence and poses questions about economic fairness.

title: PepsiCo Agrees to Pay $5 Million to Settle California Drivers’ Work Break Lawsuit
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has agreed to a $5 million settlement for claims that its California drivers were not given proper work breaks as required by state law. Approximately 1,800 current and former drivers will share the payout, with each potentially receiving about $1,990 if all participate. The lawsuit alleged drivers were not truly free of duties during breaks, as they were expected to respond to calls.

title: Michele Buck Named Lead Director, NYL Board
summary: New York Life Insurance Company has appointed Michele Buck as Lead Director of its Board of Directors, effective July 1, 2018. Ms. Buck, who is the president and CEO of The Hershey Company, has served on New York Life's Board since 2013 and will bring extensive corporate leadership and business acumen to her new role. The appointment underscores New York Life's commitment to strategic guidance and delivering financial security to its policy owners.

title: Frito-Lay’s Vivek Sankaran Elected GMA Board Chairman
summary: Vivek Sankaran, president and COO of Frito-Lay N.A., has been elected as the new chairman of the board of directors of the Grocery Manufacturers Association (GMA), effective July 1. William “Billy” Cyr, CEO of Freshpet Inc., was also elected GMA board treasurer. These leadership changes occur as the GMA undergoes a reinvention to adapt to the evolving CPG industry.

title: Small brands are attacking PepsiCo and other giants like a ‘shoal of piranhas.’ Here’s what it is doing about it
summary: PepsiCo is facing increasing competition from smaller brands and is using a "360 Always On Trend Engine" developed with Black Swan Data to predict consumer trends. This machine-learning based system analyzes online conversations to identify emerging trends and informs PepsiCo's decisions on product development and acquisitions. The company aims to stay ahead by understanding consumer desires before they become widespread.

title: Vita Coco’s parent company acquires natural energy drink Runa
summary: All Market Inc (AMI), the parent company of Vita Coco, has acquired the natural energy drink brand Runa. Both companies will operate independently under AMI, which aims to replicate Vita Coco's success with Runa, given the growing demand for clean-label energy beverages. This acquisition allows AMI to further diversify its portfolio and capitalize on the expanding natural energy drink market.

title: Investors Demand Nestle, Pepsi and Others Cut Plastic Use
summary: A group of 25 investors, managing over $1 trillion in assets, is pressuring Nestle SA, PepsiCo Inc., Procter & Gamble Co., and Unilever NV to reduce their plastic packaging use due to environmental concerns. Organized by the nonprofit shareholder advocacy group As You Sow, this initiative includes several prominent investment managers. The investors are calling for these major corporations to address the environmental damage caused by plastic waste.

title: Snarky Twitter feeds: Wendy's and White Castle's most dangerous weapon
summary: Fast-food chains like Wendy's and White Castle are leveraging snarky, engaging Twitter feeds to connect with customers and level the playing field against larger competitors. These brands aim for an authentic and witty tone, often using humor and pop culture references, while carefully avoiding controversial topics to maintain brand image. The strategy focuses on building customer loyalty and engagement rather than direct sales, with dedicated social media teams given autonomy to create real-time content.

title: Farooq Kathwari, Brian Moynihan, Stuart Weitzman Honored by Chief Executive Leadership Institute
summary: The Yale School of Management’s Chief Executive Leadership Institute honored Farooq Kathwari of Ethan Allen Interiors, Brian Moynihan of Bank of America, and Stuart Weitzman of the Stuart Weitzman footwear company at its 93rd Yale CEO Summit. The awards recognized their exceptional leadership, entrepreneurial success, and societal contributions. The summit brought together global corporate leaders and mayors for discussions on contemporary economic themes.

title: Coke, Pepsi pour more money into Initiative 1634; measure now has $2.9 million behind it
summary: Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Dr Pepper Snapple Group, and Red Bull have collectively poured $2.9 million into Initiative 1634 in Washington State. This measure aims to prevent local jurisdictions from levying taxes on sugary beverages, exempting only Seattle. The campaign, marketed as "Yes for Affordable Groceries," is predicted by NPI to receive significantly more funding from "Big Soda" as it moves towards the November ballot.

title: Amazon is getting ready to crush LaCroix
summary: Amazon and Whole Foods are challenging popular seltzer brand LaCroix by offering steep discounts on their private label 365 Everyday Value sparkling water, particularly targeting Amazon Prime members. This move is part of Amazon's strategy to leverage Whole Foods to compete with major consumer-packaged goods brands. The article also highlights the growing sparkling water market and other competitors like Pepsi's Bubly and Coca-Cola's various brands.

title: PepsiCo To Acquire Bare Snacks
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has agreed to acquire Bare Foods Co., known as Bare Snacks, a U.S.-based maker of baked fruit and vegetable snacks. Bare Snacks will continue to operate independently from its San Francisco headquarters, reporting into PepsiCo's Frito-Lay North America division. Founded in 2001, Bare Snacks started with baked apple chips and has since expanded its product line to include apple, banana, coconut, and vegetable chips made from simple, baked ingredients.

title: PepsiCo rated among top global companies for leaders
summary: PepsiCo Inc. has been named to the 2009 list of Global Top Companies for Leaders, a comprehensive study conducted by Hewitt Associates, The RBL Group, and Fortune. This recognition highlights PepsiCo's commitment to "Performance with Purpose" and talent sustainability, even through economic downturns. The study found that Global Top Companies prioritize building leadership capability and intensely focus on talent development, aligning leadership programs with business goals.

title: PepsiCo Announces Timing and Availability of Second Quarter Financial Results and Conference Call
summary: PepsiCo, Inc. announced the timing for its second quarter 2018 financial results release and subsequent conference call. The results will be posted on the company's website and furnished to the SEC on July 10, 2018, with an investor webcast scheduled for later that morning. The announcement also provides an overview of PepsiCo's global operations and business philosophy.

title: How Coke Spun the Public on its Water Use
summary: This investigation reveals that Coca-Cola significantly exaggerates its water conservation efforts, despite claiming to return as much water as it uses. The company's "water neutral" pledge focuses primarily on operational water, largely ignoring the vast amounts consumed in its supply chain, particularly for agricultural ingredients. Critics argue that many of the company's offset projects are questionable in their environmental benefit and serve commercial interests, while scientists have raised doubts about the credibility of Coca-Cola's water accounting methods.

title: PepsiCo Announces Definitive Agreement to Acquire Bare Snacks, Expanding Better-For-You Portfolio into Baked Fruit and Vegetable Snacks
summary: PepsiCo announced a definitive agreement to acquire Bare Snacks, a U.S.-based maker of baked fruit and vegetable snacks. This acquisition will expand PepsiCo's snacking portfolio and aligns with its "Performance with Purpose" vision to offer consumers healthier options. Bare Snacks will operate independently under Frito-Lay North America, with plans to innovate and expand distribution of its "better-for-you" products.

title: PepsiCo acquires healthy-snack maker Bare Snacks
summary: PepsiCo announced its plans to acquire Bare Foods Co., a producer of fruit and vegetable-based snacks. This acquisition signals PepsiCo's continued investment in the healthy snacking market.

title: PepsiCo, Inc. to Withdraw Chicago Stock Exchange Listing; Retains Nasdaq Listing
summary: PepsiCo, Inc. announced its plan to voluntarily withdraw the listing of its common stock from the Chicago Stock Exchange. The company will retain its listing on The Nasdaq Global Select Market, citing the elimination of costs associated with dual listings as the reason for the withdrawal, which is expected to be effective within the next month.

title: Campbell Soup CEO out, steel tariffs to bite soon
summary: Denise Morrison, CEO of Campbell Soup since 2011, is retiring and will be replaced by interim CEO Keith McLoughlin. The company is undergoing a strategic review as it faces declining sales, rising costs, and the impact of steel and aluminum tariffs. Campbell's also reported a third-quarter loss and lowered its full-year earnings projections.

title: The Jolly Green Giant will soon tower over Times Square
summary: B&G Foods is set to unveil two 90-foot-tall LED displays of the Jolly Green Giant in Times Square, replacing Budweiser's former ad space. This move is part of B&G Foods' strategy to reintroduce and reinvent the iconic Green Giant brand to a new generation of consumers, following a marketing push that has already resulted in significant sales increases for Green Giant frozen foods. The advertising displays represent a substantial investment, estimated at over $4 million annually, highlighting the brand's commitment to high-visibility marketing.

title: After 124 years, Hershey tries to be more than just a chocolate company (again)
summary: Hershey is attempting to transform itself into a snacking company beyond its core chocolate business, driven by slow chocolate sales growth and increased competition. This strategy involves acquiring snack brands like SkinnyPop and making its chocolate products more "snackable," while navigating its unique corporate structure tied to the Hershey Trust. The company faces a familiar challenge, having repeatedly tried and retreated from diversification efforts in the past, but current CEO Michele Buck aims for a lasting change in its portfolio and market approach.

title: Vita Coco introduces PET bottle and plans to enter sparkling space
summary: Vita Coco is expanding its product line by introducing a new PET bottle for its coconut water, exclusively at 7-Eleven, and launching a line of sparkling beverages at Kroger. These moves aim to solidify Vita Coco's market position and tap into consumer trends for healthier, more varied beverage options. The sparkling products combine coconut water with sparkling water, positioning Vita Coco as "bubbles with benefits" to appeal to a broad consumer base.

title: Frito-Lay Will Pay $2.4M to Settle Background Check Class Action Lawsuit
summary: Frito-Lay Inc. has agreed to a $2.4 million settlement in a class action lawsuit alleging violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA). The lawsuit claims Frito-Lay used consumer credit reports for background checks during hiring without proper disclosure to job applicants. The settlement, which preliminarily approves payments of at least $40 per Class Member, seeks to resolve claims that the company failed to provide a stand-alone disclosure as required by law.

title: Consumers pucker up for sour tastes, from Sour Patch Kids ice pops to pickle juice slushes
summary: Sour flavors are gaining popularity in the food and beverage industry, with new products constantly emerging. This trend is exemplified by the release of Sour Patch Kids Flavored Ice Pops and Walmart's exclusive Sour Patch Kids Red, White and Blue ice cream. Even mainstream fast-food chains like Sonic are embracing sour with plans to launch a Pickle Juice Slush.

title: The trends driving Smartfood's popcorn category leadership
summary: Smartfood, a PepsiCo brand, leads the ready-to-eat popcorn category with nearly 40% market share, driven by consumer demand for taste, nutrition, and emotional satisfaction. The brand's success is attributed to its strong flavor innovation, including the successful Smartfood Delight line, commitment to consumer obsession through research, development of single-serve options, and its direct-store delivery model. Smartfood continuously evolves, exemplified by its caramel cheddar mix, to meet changing consumer trends like the sweet and salty preference.

title: This Sustainable, Trump-Tariff-Hiked Budweiser’s for You
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev is shifting its Budweiser brand to 100% renewable energy and will mark cans accordingly, aiming to boost sales in the U.S. Amid this sustainability effort, the company faces potential price increases for consumers due to President Trump’s 10% tariff on aluminum imports. CEO Carlos Brito anticipates a 2-3% price hike on Budweiser, which relies heavily on aluminum packaging, while also announcing global renewable energy goals by 2025.

title: Cheetos Launches "Cheetos Vision" App At SXSW 2018
summary: Cheetos announced the launch of its new "Cheetos Vision" app at SXSW 2018, leveraging artificial intelligence to transform users' surroundings into Cheetos-inspired visuals. The app allows users to create and share cheesy images and videos on social media. This initiative highlights Cheetos' playful approach to technology, as stated by Rachel Ferdinando, vice president of marketing for Frito-Lay North America.

title: Water, Waste, Energy: Lessons from Coca-Cola in Africa
summary: This article examines Coca-Cola's sustainability efforts in Africa, focusing on initiatives related to water, waste, and energy. It highlights the company's vast presence and distribution network across 54 African countries, its commitment to sustainability goals aligned with global benchmarks, and specific projects like PETCO in South Africa for plastic recycling and EKOCENTERs for providing essential services. The article also discusses lessons learned, including the importance of job creation and corporate involvement in addressing Africa's development challenges.

title: Arca Continental vs. Coca-Cola Femsa, ¿a quién le fue mejor?
summary: Arca Continental significantly increased its sales by 46.4% in 2017, largely due to new operations acquired in the United States, while Coca-Cola Femsa grew by 14.7%. Despite Arca Continental's higher growth rate, Coca-Cola Femsa maintained its leadership in the sector, though analysts expressed concern over its Q4 net loss due to an accounting change related to its Venezuelan operations. Both companies face challenges from rising sugar costs and consumer preference for healthier products but are showing growth in water and non-carbonated beverages.

title: Stacy's Pita Chips Debuts "Rising To The Occasion" Original Art Packaging In Honor Of Women's History Month
summary: Stacy's Pita Chips is celebrating Women's History Month by releasing limited-edition "Rising to the Occasion" original art packaging. The company will also donate $100,000 to women's initiatives in 2018, starting with a donation to Step Up, an organization that helps girls in under-resourced communities. The new packaging features three designs symbolizing women's voices, tenacity, and unstoppable nature.

title: PepsiCo takes its vending brand Hello Goodness online to woo consumers who want healthier snacks
summary: PepsiCo is extending its "better-for-you" Hello Goodness vending brand to an online platform to capture the growing market for healthier snacks. The company is offering curated boxes of Hello Goodness products on Amazon, building on the success of its vending machines which saw significant revenue increases. This move is part of PepsiCo's broader e-commerce strategy to adapt to changing consumer shopping habits and drive impulse purchases online.

title: It’s A Wrap! McDonald’s Happy Meal Menu Will Not Have Cheeseburgers Anymore
summary: McDonald's is overhauling its Happy Meal menu to offer more "balanced" options by 2022, removing cheeseburgers as a default and making other nutritional tweaks. The move aims to reduce calories, salt, sugar, and saturated fat in children's meals. The article also criticizes McDonald's for not addressing the disproportionate impact of fast food on African-American communities and the role of "food swamps."

title: PepsiCo Posts Flat Sales, Plans to Trim Jobs
summary: PepsiCo reported flat quarterly sales due to falling demand for beverages in North America but saw its bottom line bolstered by cost-cutting efforts. The company plans to reduce its U.S. corporate workforce by less than 1% as part of a multiyear restructuring program and will issue $1,000 bonuses to its front-line workers. The food and beverage giant recorded a quarterly loss affected by U.S. tax overhaul charges and restructuring expenses.

title: PepsiCo launches bubly sparkling water
summary: PepsiCo Inc. announced the launch of bubly, a new sparkling water brand available in eight flavors across the United States. The company aims to innovate within the sparkling water category by offering a product with no artificial flavors, sweeteners, or calories, and will debut its ad campaign during the Oscars broadcast. This launch aligns with PepsiCo's commitment to its water portfolio and its Performance with Purpose goals regarding healthier beverage options.

title: JV Coca Cola del Valle New Ventures compra Novaverde por USD 80 millones en Chile
summary: Coca Cola del Valle New Ventures S.A., a joint venture among Coca Cola Company de Chile S.A., Embonor S.A., and Embotelladora Andina S.A., acquired 100% of Novaverde, a fruit and food processor, for USD 80.3 million. Novaverde, known for its Guallarauco brand, will help complement Coca Cola's product portfolio in Chile. The deal, pending approval from Chile's National Economic Prosecutor's Office, excludes Novaverde's avocado sales and General Mills representation businesses.

title: "Lady Doritos"? It's not happening, PepsiCo says
summary: PepsiCo has clarified that it is not developing a line of "lady Doritos," despite widespread online speculation. This speculation arose after former CEO Indra Nooyi's comments on a podcast about designing snacks differently for women. The company stated that the interpretation of her comments as an indication of female-specific Doritos was inaccurate.

title: PepsiCo has some ideas about what women want ... from their chips
summary: PepsiCo is considering new snack chip products, with some internal discussion about tailoring them to women's preferences, specifically mentioning a less crunchy variety. Women's groups have criticized these notions about food and gender as trite. MarketWatch clarified that PepsiCo has not yet decided to market a lower-crunch Doritos variety.

title: Oregon Fruit Products buys 165,000-square-foot plant in Salem
summary: Oregon Fruit Products is expanding its operations by acquiring a 165,000-square-foot former NORPAC Foods plant in southeast Salem. The company plans to have the facility operational by November and will continue to add employees as it grows. This move allows Oregon Fruit to address its increasingly crowded current facilities and remain in Salem, retaining its workforce and proximity to growers.

title: What Synergies Could the Dr Pepper Snapple–Keurig Merger Create?
summary: The article discusses the potential synergies arising from the merger between Dr Pepper Snapple and Keurig Green Mountain to form Keurig Dr Pepper. The new company is expected to have an extensive portfolio of 125 brands and strong distribution capabilities, aiming to generate $600 million in annual synergies by 2021 and reduce its net debt through strong cash flow. This strategic move positions the merged entity to better compete with beverage industry giants like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo.

title: The company that made coffee pods ubiquitous just dropped $18 billion on Dr. Pepper
summary: Keurig Green Mountain, known for its K-cups, has acquired an 87% stake in Dr. Pepper Snapple Group for $18.7 billion. This strategic move aims to leverage Dr. Pepper Snapple's extensive brick-and-mortar distribution network, expanding Keurig's market reach beyond online channels. The acquisition also positions Keurig to directly compete with major beverage companies like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo while challenging Starbucks' retail presence.

title: Keurig Acquires Dr Pepper Snapple; JAB Holding to be Controlling Shareholder
summary: Keurig has agreed to acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group Inc. for over $21 billion, merging them into a new entity called Keurig Dr. Pepper (KDP) with $11 billion in annual revenue. JAB Holding will be the majority shareholder, while Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share and retain a 13 percent stake. This strategic merger aims to diversify Dr Pepper Snapple's business into the growing coffee market and expand Keurig's reach across hot and cold beverage categories.

title: A Jolt of Caffeine: Keurig Acquires Dr Pepper Snapple in $18.7 Billion Deal
summary: Keurig Green Mountain Inc. is acquiring Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc. in an $18.7 billion deal to form Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP). Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share cash dividend and retain 13% of the combined company, which will have pro forma 2017 annual revenues of approximately $11 billion. This merger aims to create a scaled beverage company with a strong brand portfolio and distribution capabilities, led by Bob Gamgort as CEO.
source: Abasto, Food and Beverage Industry News
source_domain: Abasto, Food and Beverage Industry News

title: Keurig becomes $11b drink giant after buying Dr Pepper, Snapple and others
summary: Keurig will acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group, forming an US$11 billion beverage company named Keurig Dr Pepper. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive a special cash dividend of US$103.75 per share and retain a 13% stake in the combined entity. This merger brings together brands like Dr Pepper, 7 Up, Snapple, and Keurig's coffee makers, though still remains smaller than PepsiCo Inc. and Coca-Cola Co.

title: Keurig to take control of Dr Pepper Snapple in $18.7 billion deal
summary: JAB Holding's Keurig Green Mountain business has agreed to acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group in an $18.7 billion deal. This acquisition seeks to create a massive beverage distribution network in the United States, allowing the new entity, Keurig Dr Pepper, to compete with major players like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo with an estimated annual revenue of $11 billion. The merger aims to leverage the combined strengths of both companies in e-commerce and traditional retail channels to enhance market share in coffee and soft drinks.

title: Keurig buys Dr Pepper, Snapple creating $11 billion beverage behemoth
summary: Keurig Green Mountain Inc. announced its plan to acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group, forming a new beverage company named Keurig Dr Pepper with estimated annual sales of $11 billion. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in cash and retain 13 percent of the combined company. The deal, which still requires shareholder approval, is expected to close later this year.

title: Dr Pepper Snapple and Keurig Green Mountain to merge
summary: Dr Pepper Snapple Group and Keurig Green Mountain are merging to form Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP), a new beverage company with an estimated $11bn in annual sales. JAB Holdings Co. will be the controlling shareholder, while Mondelez International will hold a significant stake of around 13%. This merger aims to create a scale beverage company combining hot and cold beverages with extensive distribution capabilities in North America.

title: Keurig owner snaps up Dr Pepper in $18.7 billion deal
summary: Keurig Green Mountain, Inc. announced it will acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group, Inc. for $18.7 billion in cash, forming a new entity called Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP). This deal, driven by European consumer products giant JAB Holdings, will create a beverage company with approximately $11 billion in pro forma 2017 annual revenues and a diverse portfolio of hot and cold beverage brands. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in a special cash dividend and retain 13% of the combined company.

title: Keurig buys Dr. Pepper Snapple, creating a beverage giant
summary: Keurig Green Mountain Inc. announced its acquisition of Dr. Pepper Snapple Group, forming a new beverage giant with approximately $11 billion in annual sales. Dr. Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in a special cash dividend and retain 13 percent of the combined company, which will be named Keurig Dr. Pepper. JAB Holding company will be the controlling shareholder following the deal, expected to close in the second quarter of 2018.

title: K-Cup maker Keurig bets big on beverages, buying Dr Pepper Snapple
summary: Keurig Green Mountain announced its acquisition of Dr Pepper Snapple, creating a new beverage giant with $11 billion in annual sales. This deal allows Keurig to access Dr Pepper's distribution network and allied brands, while Dr Pepper shareholders receive a significant cash dividend. The merger is the latest strategic move by JAB Holding Company to expand its beverage empire.

title: Plano's Dr Pepper to be acquired by Keurig Green Mountain; new CEO to be based in Massachusetts
summary: Plano-based Dr Pepper Snapple Group announced a definitive merger agreement with Keurig Green Mountain, creating a company with $11 billion in revenue and moving control of the Texas brand out of state. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in cash and retain 13 percent of the combined company, with the deal valued at an estimated $18.9 billion. The new CEO will be based in Massachusetts, raising concerns about the loss of a Fortune 500 listing for North Texas.

title: Keurig, Dr Pepper Snapple Group to merge
summary: Keurig Green Mountain Inc. and Dr Pepper Snapple Group are merging to form a new beverage giant called Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP) in North America. The deal involves Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders receiving $103.75 per share in a special cash dividend, totaling $18.7 billion, and retaining 13% of KDP, while Keurig shareholders will hold 87%. This transaction will combine popular soft drink and juice brands with leading coffee brands and the Keurig single-serve coffee system, aiming for pro forma combined sales of about $11 billion.

title: Keurig to buy Dr Pepper Snapple in $21B deal
summary: Keurig Green Mountain, owned by the secretive Reimann family of Germany through JAB Holdings, has struck a deal to acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group for $18.7 billion. This merger aims to combine hot and cold beverage offerings and leverage cross-selling opportunities in channels like Walmart. The deal creates potential ripples in the fast-food industry's fountain drink market, as Dr Pepper's presence under the same umbrella as Panera Bread could lead rival Coca-Cola to press chains to switch to its Pibb Xtra.

title: Keurig Green Mountain acquiring Dr Pepper Snapple Group
summary: Keurig Green Mountain is acquiring Dr Pepper Snapple Group to create an $11 billion beverage empire called Keurig Dr Pepper. The merger aims to combine hot and cold beverage platforms, increase market scale, and achieve significant cost savings. The new company will compete with beverage giants like PepsiCo and Coca-Cola, leveraging a powerful brand portfolio and distribution capabilities.

title: Coffee meets 7UP in Keurig, Dr Pepper Snapple deal
summary: Keurig Green Mountain has merged with Dr Pepper Snapple Group Inc in a deal valued at over $21 billion, creating a North American beverage company with a wide range of hot and cold drinks. This acquisition, driven by Keurig's owner JAB Holding Co, aims to achieve significant scale and diversify their business lines, especially given the decline in sugary drink sales. The newly formed entity, "Keurig Dr Pepper," expects $600 million in cost savings and opportunities for expansion, with Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders receiving a special dividend and a 13 percent stake in the combined company.

title: More caffeine, please: Keurig is buying Dr Pepper Snapple
summary: Keurig is acquiring Dr Pepper Snapple Group to form a new beverage company, Keurig Dr Pepper, with approximately $11 billion in annual sales. This merger aims to combine hot and cold beverage offerings, expand distribution networks, and create new product opportunities like converting Dr Pepper Snapple brands into Keurig pods. The deal involves a special cash dividend for Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders and anticipates $600 million in annual cost savings.

title: Keurig Green Mountain to merge with Dr Pepper Snapple
summary: Keurig Green Mountain is merging with Dr Pepper Snapple Group to form a new company called Keurig Dr Pepper, combining coffee and beverage brands. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share and retain 13 percent of the combined entity, which expects $11 billion in annual sales and $600 million in cost savings by 2021. The transaction is expected to close in Q2 2018, and the new company will once again be publicly traded.

title: Keurig Green Mountain to buy Dr Pepper Snapple for $19B
summary: Dr Pepper Snapple announced its merger with Keurig Green Mountain for $19 billion, creating a new beverage giant with $11 billion in combined annual revenues. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in a special cash dividend and retain 13% of the combined company, with JAB Holding Co. becoming the largest shareholder through a $9 billion equity investment. This merger aims to intensify competition in the beverage market by combining traditional sodas, coffee drinks, and better-for-you beverages under one roof, leveraging a vast distribution system.

title: Dr Pepper Snapple, Keurig Green Mountain to combine to create coffee, soda giant
summary: Dr Pepper Snapple Group and Keurig Green Mountain are merging to form Keurig Dr Pepper, a beverage giant with an estimated $11 billion in annual revenues. The deal offers Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders a significant cash payment and a 13% stake in the new company, with JAB Holding becoming the controlling shareholder. This merger aims to create a "total beverage solution" with enhanced distribution capabilities and leverage in the marketplace.

title: The Yanks Have Bought Dr Pepper
summary: Keurig Green Mountain announced its acquisition of Dr Pepper Snapple Group for $18.7 billion, forming Keurig Dr Pepper with an expected $11 billion in annual revenue. While the corporate parent will be in Massachusetts, Dr Pepper's Texas headquarters and cultural significance in the state are expected to persist despite concerns about its "uniquely Texan entity." The merger is good news for shareholders, who saw a 32 percent stock surge and a dividend announcement.

title: Keurig Dr Pepper: 'A New Challenger in the Beverage Industry'
summary: Dr Pepper Snapple Group and Keurig Green Mountain have merged to form Keurig Dr Pepper (KDP), creating a new beverage company valued at $18.7 billion. This combination aims to challenge industry leaders like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo by leveraging a diverse portfolio of hot and cold beverages and extensive distribution capabilities. Dr Pepper Snapple shareholders will receive $103.75 per share in cash and retain 13% of the combined company.

title: Keurig to Acquire Dr Pepper Snapple in Largest Soft-Drink Deal Ever
summary: Keurig Green Mountain is set to acquire Dr Pepper Snapple Group Inc. in a deal valued at nearly $19 billion in cash, marking the largest nonalcoholic drinks deal on record. This merger brings together popular brands that have faced challenges from increased competition and changing consumer preferences. The transaction will create a new public company with approximately $11 billion in annual sales and over $16 billion in debt, with European investment fund JAB Holding becoming the controlling shareholder.

title: McDonald's promises to eliminate foam packaging by 2019
summary: McDonald's has agreed to eliminate all polystyrene foam packaging globally by the end of 2018, following engagement with shareholder advocacy group As You Sow. This decision comes after years of advocacy highlighting the environmental harm caused by foam packaging, particularly its impact on marine life. The company's move sets an example for other quick-service food chains to follow suit in phasing out foam and potentially other single-use plastic items.
